thread.title: Well-known rider dies after falling from horse in Tuakau
thread.title_full: Well-known rider dies after falling from horse in Tuakau

title: Well-known rider dies after falling from horse in Tuakau
text:
Well-known rider dies after falling from horse in Tuakau Last updated 11:09, February 11 2017 Supplied 
The Auckland Westpac Rescue Helicopter at the scene of the incident in Tuakau. 
A passionate dressage competitor has died after she was thrown from her horse at a property south of Auckland. 
Tributes were paid to Tracey Blackmore-Sorrell, 40, who was well known among Kiwi equestrian groups as a passionate and experienced horse rider. 
On January 30, the mother-of-two fell from the horse she was loading onto the back of a truck at a property in Tuakau. 
She was knocked unconscious and also went into a cardiac arrest, an Auckland Westpac Rescue Helicopter spokeswoman said. 
St John Ambulance staff treated her at the scene before she was flown to Auckland City Hospital in a critical condition. 
However, Blackmore-Sorrell died the next day. 
She was described in her death notice as a "soul mate" to her husband Chris Sorrell and an adoring mother to two young girls, Maddie and Hayley. 
"Tracey lived life to the fullest, always with a smile on her face and will be sorely missed by us all," the notice read. 
Sorrell posted publicly on Facebook to share the tragic news. 
"It is with a heavy heart that I advise you all the Tracey passed away yesterday after a tragic accident," he wrote. Ad Feedback 
"We appreciate all of your support and love." 
The pair owned Spurs of Counties, an online saddlery store, and Blackmore-Sorrell competed in dressage competitions across New Zealand for more than 20 years. 
Dressage Clinics New Zealand also paid tribute on Facebook. 
"It is with sadness we report the passing of Tracey Blackmore-Sorrell. Tracey was a passionate dressager and was in her third decade as a dressage competitor. 
"Our condolences to Tracey's family." 
A service for Blackmore-Sorrell was held in the garden of her parents home in Coatesville on Wednesday. 
The family thanked all emergency services and hospital staff for their care and support. - Stuff
